question: In 2015, the Port of Seattle leased its vacant Terminal 5 to which company?
description: The Port of Seattle signed a two-year contract with [Foss Maritime](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/foss-maritime-floats-plan-to-use-portrsquos-terminal-5/), which originally planned to use the space as a home port for Shell Oil’s Arctic drilling fleet. Shell has since ceased all offshore drilling in the Arctic.
caption: Paul Gallagher, Vice President of Terminal Services for Foss Maritime, in front of the Polar Pioneer oil drilling rig, docked at Terminal 5 in Seattle.

question: Which of these companies captured the largest venture-capital funding round this year?
description: **Adaptive Biotechnologies**, which examines the genetic makeup of the immune system to help fight cancer, [raked in $195 million](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/seattle-startups-raised-11b-in-first-6-months-of-2015/) in May and a total of nearly $400 million. In comparison, business-software company K2 raised $153 million, and online legal marketplace [Avvo](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/technology/moneytree-report-places-3q-vc-financing-in-state-at-327m/) raised $71.5 million.

question: How many stores did Bellingham-based grocery chain Haggen buy after this year’s Albertsons-Safeway merger?
description: Haggen [bought 146 of the 168 stores](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/local-business/bellingham-based-haggen-growing-from-18-stores-to-164/) jettisoned in the Albertsons-Safeway merger, but later filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and is now planning to offer all the stores up for auction.
caption: Rick Haggen, whose family started the company during the Depression, stands outside the Bellingham store.

question: Which of these companies was bought by Warren Buffett’s investment conglomerate Berkshire Hathaway in 2015?
description: Berkshire Hathaway [agreed to pay $37.2 billion](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/buffett-to-acquire-portlands-precision-castparts-in-372b-deal/) to buy Portland-based **Precision Castparts**, maker of aerospace and energy equipment. Berkshire Hathaway bought into insurance company Symetra in 2004 but sold its interest earlier this year.
caption: A Precision Castparts worker in Portland inspects a part that will go on an aircraft engine.

question: What is this object?
description: The object is a **heat exchanger** from one of the Apollo 16 rocket engines. It was retrieved from the ocean and [donated to the Museum of Flight](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/boeing-aerospace/apollo-12-engine-rescued-by-bezos-goes-to-museum-of-flight/) this year.
caption: The engine piece sits inside a wooden delivery crate.

question: Which building was NOT acquired this year by Chinese investors eager for a secure and stable place for their money?
description: **Weyerhaeuser's** [award-winning headquarters](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/weyerhaeuser-campus-draws-global-admirers/) in Federal Way is still for sale, as it has been since August 2014. Hong Kong-based Gaw Capital Partners [bought](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/columbia-center-sold/) the 76-story Columbia Center for $711 million in August. In November, Pacific Eagle, the San Francisco subsidiary of Hong Kong-based Great Eagle Holdings, [reached a deal](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/hong-kong-company-set-to-buy-dexter-horton-building/) to buy Dexter Horton, which dates back to 1924.
photographer: Thomas James Hurst / The Seattle Times
caption: Weyerhaeuser’s headquarters building is considered one of the finest examples of modern architecture on the West Coast.

question: "4/C," the 101-story tower proposed for downtown Seattle, would include which of the following?
description: Developers of the 101-story tower say it will include an [earthquake-dampening water pool](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/seattle-about-to-enter-elite-skyscraper-club/) at its top.
caption: The proposed facade for the 1,111-foot skyscraper features carved edges and segmentation to avoid appearing monolithic.

question: Which of these local deals, all announced in 2015, was the biggest?
description: In November, Weyerhaeuser announced it was buying [Plum Creek](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/weyerhaeuser-plum-creek-to-combine-into-one-timber-giant/) for $8.4 billion to form the nation’s largest private owner of timberland. In comparison, home-shopping giant QVC bought Zulily in a $2.4 billion cash-and-stock deal announced in August and Expedia said in November it was buying vacation-rental company [HomeAway](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/expedia-buys-homeaway-for-39-billion/) for $3.9 billion.
caption: Plum Creek Timber owns about 6 million acres of forest and conservation lands in 19 states.

question: The city of SeaTac currently has the highest minimum wage within the state for certain workers. What is that minimum wage?
description: Since January 1, the minimum wage for workers in SeaTac has been [$15.24 an hour](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/economy/states-high-court-extends-seatac-minimum-wage-to-airport-workers/).
caption: Seattle City Council member Kshama Sawant stands with airport workers and supporters at Sea-Tac Airport.

question: Local space-technology company Tethers Unlimited uses a highly customized machine to braid strong fibers of metalized Kevlar into long space tethers. What was the $150,000 machine’s original purpose?
description: Tethers Unlimited’s Rob Hoyt went to Japan to buy a machine [**originally designed to make lace**](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/boeing-aerospace/greater-seattle-area-companies-embrace-space-quest/) for kimonos and lingerie.
caption: Robert Hoyt, CEO at Tethers Unlimited, Inc., holds the Hoytether, a space teather made with a special braiding machine.

question: What new business will Amazon NOT be entering in 2016?
description: October was a busy month for Amazon. On Oct. 7, the Seattle company introduced business applications to help companies [analyze the data](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/amazon/amazon-jumps-into-market-for-business-data-analysis/) they’re storing on AWS servers. The next day it [launched a site](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/amazon/amazon-takes-on-etsy-launches-craft-site-handmade/) that offers handmade crafts in competition with Etsy. But no word yet on **driverless-car delivery**.
caption: Valerie Nethery of Seattle makes gold jewelry that she is selling on Handmade at Amazon as well as Etsy.

question: Which of these companies had the largest stock gain for the year? (Percent gain, as of Dec. 18 close.)
description: While all three blue-chip companies enjoyed gains, **Amazon** blew away the field with a 114 percent increase in its stock price, closing Dec. 18 at $664.14 a share.
caption: Senior site leader Darrin Scharffenorth at Amazon’s Kennewick center.

question: The Northwest Seaport Alliance, finalized last summer, unifies the marine-cargo division of which two seaports?
description: **Seattle and Tacoma** Port commissioners voted in August to [join forces](http://www.seattletimes.com/business/international-trade/seattle-tacoma-ports-ok-bold-alliance-in-marine-cargo-business/) in worldwide competition for marine cargo.
caption: Crews work at a K Line container ship at Terminal 4 at the Port of Tacoma.

question: What company bought Seattle-based craft brewery Elysian in early 2015?
description: **Anheuser-Busch** bought the 20-year-old [Elysian Brewing company](http://old.seattletimes.com/html/businesstechnology/2025528085_anheuserelysianxml.html) in January. Terms have not been disclosed.
caption: Elysian's Capitol Hill brewery is located on E. Pike Street.
